Default introduction.Message: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

Video.Text: Here's a video to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.

List of tips.Message: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

Option 1: Try to redirect your child’s a.Message:
1. Try to redirect your child's attention

When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

Option 2: Make sure it is a behaviour yo.Message 1:
2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
Option 2: Make sure it is a behaviour yo.Message 2: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
Option 2: Make sure it is a behaviour yo.Message 3: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

Option 3: Ignore the behaviour not your.Message 1:
3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
Option 3: Ignore the behaviour not your.Message 2: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
Option 3: Ignore the behaviour not your.Message 3: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

Option 4: Praise your child immediately.Message 1:
4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
Option 4: Praise your child immediately.Message 2: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

Option 5: Be consistent when ignoring.Message 1:
5. Be consistent when ignoring

Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
Option 5: Be consistent when ignoring.Message 2: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
Option 5: Be consistent when ignoring.Message 3: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

Option 6: Make sure you are giving your.Message 1:
6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
Option 6: Make sure you are giving your.Message 2: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
